award_name.ja: Best Poster Award of Renewable Energy 2006

paper_title.en: Nickel-catalyzed carbonization of wood for coproduction of functional carbon and fluid fuels II: improved fuel quality of oil fraction and increased heating value of gas fraction

description.en: The yields and properties of oil and gas fractions coproduced during carbonization of larch wood loaded with Ni 2%, Ni 2%+Ca 1%, and Ni 4% and without catalyst (None) at 700A degrees-900A degrees C were examined to clarify the catalytic effect in terms of conversion into fluid fuels. The net calorific value of oil occurred mainly below 500A degrees C and increased in the order None < Ni 2% < Ni 4% < Ni 2%+Ca 1%, while the yield decreased in this order. The same order held for the production of gases enriched with hydrogen at 500A degrees-700A degrees C. Even above 800A degrees C, markedly promoted evolution of hydrogen took place for all catalyst systems. These observations confirmed the effectiveness of nickel-catalyzed carbonization at 900A degrees C, particularly Ni 2%+Ca 1%, for both upgrading of oil and gaseous fractions, although the quality of oil was not satisfactory. The catalysis of nickel with and without calcium is discussed on the basis of the modified Broid-Shafizadeh scheme, and the scheme was altered to adapt to the high temperature region where oil was no longer produced.

paper_title.ja: 木タール配合粉炭の熱圧成形による固体燃料の製造
900℃ニッケル触媒炭素化で調製した木質炭素化物の導電性とナノ構造
paper_title.en: Electro-conductivity and nanostructure of wood carbon prepared by nickel-catalyzed carbonization at 900℃

description.ja: Wood carbon prepared by nickel-catalyzed carbonization at 900°C followed by washing with acid for removal of the metal was oxidized in a muffle furnace at 480°C. This eliminated the amorphous region selectively, and the residual carbon became superior to a commercial electro-conductive carbon, Denka black, in the performance. Observations by scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy disclosed that the crystallite region in the original wood carbon had a novel graphitic nanostructure. It is noted that such a uniquely morphological graphitic carbon can be inexpensively and easily produced from woody biomass.
description.en: Wood carbon prepared by nickel-catalyzed carbonization at 900°C followed by washing with acid for removal of the metal was oxidized in a muffle furnace at 480°C. This eliminated the amorphous region selectively, and the residual carbon became superior to a commercial electro-conductive carbon, Denka black, in the performance. Observations by scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy disclosed that the crystallite region in the original wood carbon had a novel graphitic nanostructure. It is noted that such a uniquely morphological graphitic carbon can be inexpensively and easily produced from woody biomass.

paper_title.en: High electroconductivity of wood char obtained by iron-catalyzed carbonization

description.en: A disk specimen prepared from char obtained by carbonizing 3 wt % iron-loaded larch at 850 degrees C was superior and comparable to those from acetylene black and Ketjenblack, respectively, in electroconductivity. Subsequent soaking of the wood char in a diluted acid for removal of the metal led to improvement in the quality to surpass the level of Ketjenblack. Also, the carbonization with 3 wt % iron at 850 degrees C was more effective than that with 2wt% nickel at 900 degrees C for enhancing the conductivity. The more favorable catalysis of iron can be elucidated by the formation of finer nanocarbon particles with higher mesoporosity to compensate for the less crystallinity.

paper_title.en: Crystallinity and mesoporosity of carbon produced from ligno-p-cresol and their improvement by pulverization and acid treatment

description.en: Crystallized mesoporous carbon was produced from ligno-p-cresol, a lignin derivative obtained by phase separation with p-cresol and sulfuric acid, onto which 3% nickel and 2% calcium were co-loaded, by carbonization at 900 degrees C. Subsequent pulverization followed by soaking in acid improved the crystallinity of carbon with an increased volume of mesopore, attaining approximately 90% and 99% removal of nickel and calcium, respectively. These aspects implied both enhancement of electroconductivity and liquid phase adsorption capacity of the carbon with a good outlook on the recovery and reuse of the two metals. In particular, combination of wet milling using small beads and mild soaking with diluted acid was appropriate in respect of relevant properties of the carbon, including the particle size. It can thus be concluded that incorporation of such post-treatments into the manufacturing process of carbon products is greatly advantageous.

paper_title.en: Nickel-catalyzed carbonization of wood for coproduction of functional carbon and fluid fuels I: production of crystallized mesoporous carbon

description.en: Japanese larch wood loaded with nickel (1% - 4%) alone or with nickel and calcium (0.25% - 1.5%) was carbonized at 800 degrees - 900 degrees C for 0 - 120 min with a heating rate of 5 degrees - 20 degrees C min(-1) in a helium flow of 5.8 - 46.4 ml STP cm(-2) min(-1) to examine the influence of these variables on the crystallization of carbon ( the formation of T component) and the development of mesoporosity. From the obtained results, reaction conditions suitable for effective production of carbon with the dual functions of adequate electroconductivity and adsorption capacity in liquid phase were established, thereby explaining the factors that govern the process. It was also confirmed that mesopore having a diameter of about 4 nm was selectively produced at the cost of specific ( BET) surface area in parallel with the formation of T component. This result provided good insight into how the simultaneous dual function could be realized.

paper_title.en: Nickel-catalyzed carbonization of wood for coproduction of functional carbon and fluid fuels I: production of crystallized mesoporous carbon

description.en: Japanese larch wood loaded with nickel (1% - 4%) alone or with nickel and calcium (0.25% - 1.5%) was carbonized at 800 degrees - 900 degrees C for 0 - 120 min with a heating rate of 5 degrees - 20 degrees C min(-1) in a helium flow of 5.8 - 46.4 ml STP cm(-2) min(-1) to examine the influence of these variables on the crystallization of carbon ( the formation of T component) and the development of mesoporosity. From the obtained results, reaction conditions suitable for effective production of carbon with the dual functions of adequate electroconductivity and adsorption capacity in liquid phase were established, thereby explaining the factors that govern the process. It was also confirmed that mesopore having a diameter of about 4 nm was selectively produced at the cost of specific ( BET) surface area in parallel with the formation of T component. This result provided good insight into how the simultaneous dual function could be realized.

paper_title.en: Preparation of crystallized and mesoporous carbon by nickel-catalyzed carbonization of wood

description.en: Char composed of crystallized carbon (T component) and enriched with mesopore was obtained by carbonization of nickel-loaded wood at 850 and 900 degrees C for 1 h in a flow of nitrogen, although the corresponding treatment of wood without nickel gave amorphous and microporous carbon. This also disclosed a close relationship between the production of T component and the formation of mesopore. The crystallized and mesoporous wood carbon that can possess a double function of electroconductivity adequate for electromagnetic shielding and adsorption capacity comparable to that of coal-derived activated carbon is a promising high-quality carbon electrode material.

paper_title.en: Preparation of crystallized and mesoporous carbon by nickel-catalyzed carbonization of wood

description.en: Char composed of crystallized carbon (T component) and enriched with mesopore was obtained by carbonization of nickel-loaded wood at 850 and 900 degrees C for 1 h in a flow of nitrogen, although the corresponding treatment of wood without nickel gave amorphous and microporous carbon. This also disclosed a close relationship between the production of T component and the formation of mesopore. The crystallized and mesoporous wood carbon that can possess a double function of electroconductivity adequate for electromagnetic shielding and adsorption capacity comparable to that of coal-derived activated carbon is a promising high-quality carbon electrode material.

research_project_title.ja: 木材由来導電性メソ孔炭素の電気二重層キャパシタ電極特性

description.ja: 鉄系触媒を添加して900℃前後炭化して得られる導電性メソ孔炭素を賦活処理して電気二重層キャパシタ電極性能を調査する

research_project_title.ja: バイオマス熱分解タールの利用法開発

description.ja: バイオマス炭化で副生するタールから高性能バインダー等として利用する技術、機能性炭素＋軽質油＋水素に転換する技術などを開発する。

research_project_title.ja: バイオマスの触媒炭化による機能性木炭の製造

description.ja: 木質系バイオマスに鉄系触媒（ニッケル、鉄）を添加して種々の温度で炭化し、易ガス化性や水素化触媒能、導電性や高分子の液相吸着能等を備えた機能性炭素を製造する

research_project_title.ja: 木材炭化物の低温接触ガス化

description.ja: 木質原料にニッケルもしくは鉄触媒前駆体を水溶液含浸担持して500℃炭化するとこれら金属を高分散担持した木炭が得られる。この金属担持木炭は水素中では700℃以下、水蒸気中では800℃以下で高効率でそれぞれCH4、H2＋CO+CO2に転換される。
